course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Globalization in Everyday Life
course.description: This course is designed for students who are interested to explore how their personal lives have been shaped by globalization. We will start by asking questions about some of the most relatable everyday experiences: How do we become so reliant on and addicted to Internet? Why are we faced with increasingly frequent disasters, like pandemic? And what structure our constantly changing tastes for pop culture? We will find answers to these questions through the lens of neoliberalism, a political economic ideology that has transformed the world since the 1980's, and with reference to some interesting and in-depth case studies.

reviews.author: cookie357
reviews.title: Better than SOSC1980 (really)
reviews.comment_content:
This course pretends to be an introduction to globalization, but it's actually not true. An accurate name for this course would be "Capitalists are bad and globalization is their evil scheme REEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE"

After this course you become a bona fide, certified leftard who knows how to hate on anything on demand. No critical thinking required.

Syllabus attached below. (and some slides but file size is bs)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Amusing.

She frequently bashes evil, greedy capitalists and their minions, e.g.:

Milton Friedman is that crazy guy who thinks the poor should be responsible for their failure

Thomas Edison made light bulb so that you can work 24/7

And so on..

It's also fun when she talks about patriarchy and male gaze in mario.

Research interests:
• Global China
• Southeast Asia
• Infrastructure Finance
• Migration and Diaspora Politics
• Gender and Intimate Economies
• Feminist Methodologies

I think you understand where I'm going with this.

(https://sosc.hkust.edu.hk/people/wanjing-kelly-chen)

reviews.comment_workload:
Trivial.

Attendance is a joke and you can get full marks just by doing canvas survey at the right time (i.e. zoom at home)

Participation is a giveaway (lowest score is 8/10).
Don't listen to the other review, it's not worth sitting at the first row and talks with professor 1-to-1 every lecture just for that pitiful 2 marks lmao

For MCQ just read the slides before exam. There are some words that leftists invented so you need to memorize them. Reading are useless and long (no one would read that 340 page "Rare Earth Frontiers") so avoid them.

Essay questions are easy. Just write fast and furiously. Muster your hate for greedy riches and unleash it at once.

There is no assignment, just saying. Unless you want to get that extra 1 mark by taking photos of "pink tax"

reviews.author: wkwkwkkwkw
reviews.title: Good course
reviews.comment_content:
Module 1: Introducing Globalization
- Defining Globalization
- The Structural Adjustment Programs
Module 2: Free Trade Dilemma
- Fordism/Post-Fordism
- Planet Apparels and Rare Earth Frontier
- Political Responses to Free Trade
Module 3: Uneven Mobility
- Mobility Economy
- Flexible Citizenship
- Refugee and Diaspora
Module 4: The Dire and Desire of Technology
- Our Digital Globe
- Surveillance Capitalism and Ghost Labor
- Technology and Future

Pretty interesting. Quite fun to study to be honest (I expected it to be boring).
reviews.comment_teaching: I think this is Professor Chen's first time teaching a course here in HKUST. But I do think she does quite well in teaching, she definitely has passion in the subject being taught to the class. She is also very considerate and kind, she is very generous when grading your essays. She does expect you to participate in the lectures though.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading, the A cutoff is quite high (need at least 90). Kind of unfair honestly, but the course is quite easy so it shouldn't be that hard.

10% Attendance
10% Participation
40% Midterm
40% Finals

OR

10% Attendance
10% Participation
20% Midterm
20% Finals
40% Term Paper

Attendance:
- Attend lectures and do the surveys conducted after each lecture.
- My grade: 10/10 (Mean: 8.6)

Participation:
- Participate in class, give your ideas and answer her questions.
- My grade: 10/10 (Mean: 8.96)

Midterm (covers Module 1 and 2)
- 20 MCQ (3 marks each) and 2 essay questions (Choose 1, worth 40 marks)
- Pretty doable. The MCQ was not that hard but I screwed up a bit :P. You will definitely get a good grade for the essay section if you studied the case studies Prof Chen gave you.
- My grade (MCQ): 42/60
- My grade (Essay): 39/40
- My total midterm grade: 81/100 (Mean 68.5)

Finals (covers Module 3 and 4)
- She made the MCQs much easier than they were in the midterm (she said it was so that our grades could be higher lmao). The essay's difficulty was the same for the finals.
- My grade (MCQ): 51/60
- My grade (Essay): 40/40
- My final grade: 94/100 (+3 from extra credits) (Mean: 73/100)

Term Paper (optional)
- If you want to choose the second way of grading in this course then you are required to write a term paper.

My total grade: 90.
Letter Grade: A.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light. Just attend lectures and participate.
